140671430.review:
[olist]
[*]No dedicated key for Pause button.
[*]Cannot skip dialogue all together. You can fast forward it so that is a lot of clicks.
[*]Tedious repetitive dialogues to do the same activity again and again. Un-necessary follow up conversation - like I just want to buy my license and be done or sell my item for the 3 millionth time, why do I have to listen to the same follow up conversation that I cannot just one-key-press escape. 
[*]Small small small map.
Map is not built for transportation. Want to carry that Amber Chunk in your pocket? You can't - you can a whole engine that you found but you can't this particular item.

[*]Planting seeds - I don't know if I am doing this wrong, but planting a tree goes as such 1.Dig a hole. 2. drop a seed 3.Plug that hole with soil. Now if you want to do this say 400 times for a big tree farm imagine doing that over an over.  You can try putting down multiple seeds but they can get clubbed together and when you pick up one you pick up both. And if you drop two seeds - it won't just plant one and leave one be instead it won't plant at all.
[*]Game is not scaled to do massive projects. Want to expand the land? Or flatten it? Sure - you can do it one block at time. Which is fine - but your tool that degrades and eventually breaks if you over use it to the end. So better make 20 of these or just be ready to spend several days flattening a huge area. Or make 10 of those charging stations to keep cycling through them. 
[*]Again - Giant animals but not enough land to house them. Want to do a 100 wombat farm? You going to need a ton of land, but not for the animals silly. Its for the housing that shelters the animals.
[*] The whole petting the animal nonsense. Not a fan even once you are in possession of the musical instrument.
[*]Some tools break some you can recharge. Helmet - recharges does not break but any other powertool breaks? Why?
[*]Sleep to save system. Did you enjoy flattening that 2 mile long area that took you long time to flatten? Great you were so excited that forgot that tool was about to at its last usage and broke? No worries just don't save and start over. Yes you will have to do that whole flattening again.
[*]Flowers? Can we make colors out of this yet or not?
[*]Bats - fun to kill. Till you keep getting hordes of them while mining. Even with two bat-zappers you will run out of them. The game's philosophy is progression = 10x of the same item.
Anyway, spent ton of hours on this - but game still feels as tedious as it is on Day1 (IN-GAME) you would think after few years worth of days in game and pretty much unlocking everything it would be easier to do massive projects? But no. What is the end goal of this game if not that? It is not minecraft with procedural endless regeneration.

[/olist]

The PC version of animal crossing, minus the long real-life wait times. 
You can keep customising your own village to your hearts desire and the one dev that is making this game keeps adding content to this game [b] and interacts with the community [/b]. There is a grind-aspect to it but it feels very natural, as you progress the grind dies down as you can automate a lot of the stuff. The graphics aren't anything mind-blowing but they are nice. Some bird sounds may sound low quality and the music may get repetitive after a while, but nothing a nice spotify list can't fix.
This game is well worth it's price and James deserves your money for making solo a way better game than some huge corporations can come up with.

140639639.review:
Dinkum is an amazing title that is rough around the edges.

There's not a lot of depth when it comes to npcs and story. The main interaction you will have with npcs is by completing request for them. "bring me fish/food/furniture/clothing or can i buy this from you/do you want to buy this from me?"
Requests are worth it to get new items/blueprints, but you don't learn anything about the npcs by doing them. It also has a frustrating relationship decay mechanics.

Then there's building. That's where the game shines. You can place npcs houses wherever you want, you can build wherever and whatever you want. The main drawback is the fact that you can't create roofs (due to coding, one ítem per title) community found a workaround by using bridges as roofs, but It's not a perfect solution.

Creative ppl will have a blast, and can spend tonsss of time on this game. I spent 100hrs and I only created like 5% of things I wanted to make.
Building aside, the game feels pretty lifeless. So if you try to focus on anything but building you might get bored and rather disappointed with this title.

140427683.review: All around it's an enjoyable experience on both single and multiplayer. I do wish that there was some kind of system where the host could allow certain players to have full capability on the game, however I'm not sure if that is in the works. It can be quite buggy at times, but it is a very cute and charming game. The change to the food buffing is definitely a grievance of mine, though I understand not wanting to make it too overpowered (Edit: I am now aware it was a bug, phew XD). I wish singular players could go into the mines in multiplayer mode without the host, and I hope to see that changed in the future (perhaps as an edition to giving certain members full permissions). All in all, it's quite a fun game with nice music and charming characters, and I hope to see their personalities expanded upon a bit more in future updates. The animals are cute, with quite challenging enemies (though they get much easier as you acquire better weapons) and a fun and quite large mine system. I look forward to future updates, and I definitely recommend a purchase!

140427512.review:
[b] Obligatory TL;DR because I ramble too much [/b] - if you like the genre, and don't mind how the multiplayer works, 100% buy this game and I personally think if you can, pay full price and support a legit solo dev! I would say it's 8.5/10 with the only things stopping it from being higher for me can mostly be boiled down to "Early Access jank". Detailed ramblings that resemble a review below.

I am a veteran Harvest Moon, AC, Rune Factory etc player based in Australia. These games are my Vegemite (or I suppose, Mighty, in Dinkum's case) on toast. This game to me is worth full price right now with the amount of content it has, and with more major updates on the way. Obviously, it has its bugs and flaws as most Early Access games tend to, but most of the time, it's nothing making sure your saves are backed up won't fix.

The main thing that helps Dinkum stand out and shine is the setting for sure. Many people, Aussie and not, I've streamed the game for have said "wow, this is exactly how I imagine a HarvestCrossing Australian Flavoured game to be". While Dinkum isn't necessarily a "lore heavy" game like some others in the genre, I really like the little tidbits we hear about the world "before things went South" and about "South City" as we have people move to our island and befriend them. Essentially, the premise of Dinkum is the world has gone South (aka to Jackaroo Poo), and Fletch, an elderly woman, puts out an ad one day about a once-in-a-lifetime chance to get out of South City that you the player are the only one who takes interest in. She tells you about the island, which is where her father lived many years ago, and provides you his old journal (which functions as your "achievement" system and progression tracking namely) and you get on an airship and go from there!

The overall "mechanics" of the game are incredibly familiar with, but there are things like the licenses, and Franklyn's shop, that are distinct enough that it's hard for me to 1:1 compare Dinkum to another game mechanically, or for me to say that it feels "too similar" to another game. One thing I like and wish was more common in the Harvest Moon series is when you make meals at your cooking table, they all have certain unique buffs! These buffs both make it easier to do that action and also affect your EXP. For example, if a food has a sword and a shield icon in it, that means it buffs your attack and defense. On the note of combat, for anyone expecting the game to be combat heavy, you will likely be disappointed to hear the combat is fairly basic and not necessarily a required part of the game until you start getting into the endgame. But that doesn't bother me personally, if I want a more combat heavy game in the genre, I'll go play RF4 or SDV. My favourite part of the progression would have to be the things you unlock via Franklyn, especially things like the motorbike or helicopter (which is a cool 3 million dinks and many Shiny Disc sacrifices :P). Yes, you read that right, the money is literally called Dinks :D

Regarding co-op/multiplayer, it can be a bit buggy and janky at certain points, but for the most part I like how it is. The only major gripe I have about it is if we want to pause, the only way to do that it seems is by ending the day (which for reference Dinkum days are about 30 mins irl time if you use the full day). Aside from that, I like the travel bag system (a "global" backpack for taking things to others islands) and the fact that it's easy to avoid getting burned if you're trading because of how the save system works (which is, the game only saves when you start a new day). I know some people have complaints it's not "true" co-op, in the sense of it isn't it's own separate save or mode, but rather you take your character and your items in your inventory and travel bag to someone's island, or they come to yours. However, you can still work on things for your own island on someone else's, such as your relationship/hearts progression with NPCs or doing things like bug catching, fishing, mining etc. etc. to work on your "exp" for those skills, so it's not like co-op not being hosted on your island is a detriment to you, especially because time won't progress on your island while you're on someone else's, it only progresses their day. I get the complaints and if this is a deal breaker for you that is understandable, given how games like SDV have much more refined co-op/multiplayer comparatively. At the same time it is only in Early Access, so this may change once the game releases, especially since the Developer has said he would like to work on bringing Dinkum to non-PC platforms once the game is officially "done" and released out of Early Access (this is in the FAQs on the community Discord). 

The only negative for me personally is the fishing is a biiiit janky, which is a relatively common "negative" people cite. I actually preferred the old button mash system as a controller player though I understand the reasoning for the minor rework. The main reasons I wanted to call this out are because 1) fishing is how you get the current anniversary event currency, and 2) fishing one of the ways you can make a lot of Dinks, and is pretty easy to do so especially once you have the jetski and the Fishing Book from Theodore's Museum. I haven't heard many people say they actively *like* the fishing system, so do be prepared for some minor frustrations in that department.

140419056.review:
It's one of those games you initially like and are really excited about until that epiphany hits you "WHY AM I PLAYING THIS GAME?"

Once you get to the "end game" you realise there is nothing to do, there is zero incentive to do anything in this game. The creator of this game is trying to milk the early access for as long as possible. The updates are just time buffers that add just more things onto your to do list but are seldom fun or creative in anyway. What is the point in a sandbox that offers no reward and is hollow? This game has so much potential but the road map is boring and un-innovative. Every new thing is just more work and it creates this time wasting simulator. Everything is a rip off from Animal crossing. We get it's the aussie version of Animal crossing ... BUT it could be soo much more! I think the guy who created this game is so scared to take the risks it needs to be a solid game that can be replayed many times over but once you beat it initially, you have no reason to ever pick it up ever again! Stardew valley handles this problem so well, even talking about Stardew makes me want to replay it again but this game ... you just have an overwhelming feeling of dread that prevents you from exploring this hollow husk of what could be a GREAT game but instead all you have is a copy and paste cash grab that makes you feel like a chump for buying into it

I want to see this game progress past the point of adding some element of an end game and overall point and not just cutting things from other games and pasting it in because it's a safe bet.

This is a fantastic game, and what I really don't get is the constant moaning about the "fake coop". Yes, it has room for improvement, but I do not feel like a +1 in our island and yes I am the second player. I just did the first story quests in like 20 mins and then joined the other players island. I just cant place houses, but we can decide that together. I can still help pay the debt, bring the materials etc. I can't bring the people to the island, but we both do the tasks anyways so what does that matter really? Only real gripe I have is that I can't go into the mine alone and the NPC-s don't really react to me 5 staring them, felt like a bit of a waste of time going to max with them. We just built a guest house, and that's my house. I furnish it, I build around it, I live there. It works fantastically in coop, no problems whatsoever (except that villager friendship meter thing).

So take all of these 45 minutes played "fake coop" callers with a grain of salt, they barely played past the first story missions. At first I was a bit pissed as well, but I very quickly realised that I was not nearly as limited as I thought I was going to be. The coop definitely needs some work and a fully implemented system would be 100% the best, but it is completely playable currently.

140226687.review:
Very much enjoying my time in Dinkum. Very much a casual game; but the town feels like a place I created, the peoples quirks are interesting and all the mechanics are fairly solid.

100hrs in and still finding new things, and have a list of things to unlock, but that's the beauty of this game, take it at your own pace, fast or slow, it's up to you. But the more you engage, the more fun you seem to have.

A day is roughly 30-45 min, so you'll need multiples of that to play. Unlock initially can be slow (and at times a little perplexing), but there are guides galore when you get a little stuck. But I think the pace of the unlocks are about right.

Combat gets progressively easier as soon as you learn the move sets; and assuming you remember to heal up...  The vehicles are all quite fun and have their moments; 

Generally been rock solid, occasional bugs, but better put together than many early access games.

Would I recommend it? yes, and I am to keep playing for some time.

This would be a maybe recommendation. I enjoyed my time with the game, but some problems are too big for me to ignored, and I hope they are fixed by the full release:
1 - Please!!! make it so when you open a menu it paused the game. I don't want to have to go to the tittle screen every time I need to step away from the game and loose everything I did since the start of the day. And when I need to step away isn't always at night when I sleep. 
2 - Similarly, it's not okay that animals can attack me when I am in a cut scene. An alligator attack me when I was speaking with the grandma when we arrived on the island. I was also attacked when I was looking at the board with the demand or when I had just catch a bug and it played the cute animation. 
3 - I got no info on how to drive the wheelbarel so I was just confused until i try everything on my controler. I think leaving the player figure some things outs is nice, but I don't think this is one of them, since it is specific to this game and no one will instinctively know how to do it. 

Overall, this game will be great, but I think I will wait a bit so those issues are fixed and then played more. I hope the developpers are aware of the first two problems the most and fix it or the game will just be more annoying than fun for me. 

Also, I played on the steam deck and got no problem specific to it I can recall, it was pretty smooth.

[h1] Review of Dinkum! YES! [/h1]


* [b]Immediate reaction:[/b] So much yes. Cute visuals, intuitive controls, and peaceful audio.

* [b]Within 10 hours of gameplay:[/b] My boyfriend and I are both addicted, separately. (We don’t know how to join each other’s islands yet, but we don’t care, we’re so happy on our individual islands.)

* [b] At ~50 hours of gameplay,[/b] we visited each other's islands briefly. We are having very different game experiences. He's flying a helicopter, riding a jetski, and trapping angry cassowary-emus. 139639671.review:
It's taken me a while to think about how to write this review, but here it goes...
Dinkum is a beautifully wholesome game with a fresh blend of unique & familiar game styles. The simplicity in the game ui & character controls makes it easy to pick up and hard to put down. You can lose many hours of your life in this game and not regret a single second of it.
I'm a particularly a big fan of the animals and interactions with them the game offers. So many other games of this nature go for fantasy or more western animals so to play with Australian animals is refreshing and just as adorable as usual. Pick up a guitar and -bam- you've got the cutest audience for your little performance. 
The game doesn't hold back when it comes to the survival elements, a backpack full of grub is often needed to get from one place to another. Angry critters will run after you too, I find the encounters engaging but never too difficult for me to manage. 
Overall, Dinkum is chock full of endearing qualities all put together in a bright and eye-catching graphic design, James has done a truly wonderful job creating this game. There are things that could be improved but this game is in early access so I'll give it the benefit of "maybe eventually it will all work out"
For a game that is very new it runs very smoothly and with few bugs, I can safely say it's one of the best early access games I have ever had the pleasure of playing.

Here's where we get to the *but*...
Whilst I would recommend the game I'd advise extreme caution when engaging with the online Dinkum community. I met some of the most amazing people and truly felt I'd found somewhere I belonged, but it was short lived. I was one of a group of people accused of being "too helpful" and was very confused and upset. When I did eventually gather myself and make a heartfelt apology I was responded to with a message that started "I'm not reading that" and then banned. I'm still under the belief that there was severe misunderstanding and miscommunication from both myself & the admin team but this thing isn't what upsets me the most. When I say I met amazing people I do truly mean it, and those amazing people were also cut off and bullied out of the server. I've heard some horrible things about what happens behind the scenes and the bias certain people show towards others, I have seen messages from the community manager that I would never expect anyone to send let alone somebody in charge of a massive network of gamers (some of which were/are incredibly vulnerable). With all of this some of our friends reached out to James himself and he made it clear that he supports the actions of this CM and so I feel I cannot support the game anymore.
I loved this game, adored it, I put so much of myself into it and dedicated myself to helping others wherever I could, but now when I even look at it in my games menu I feel sick to the core. Not only was it an extremely traumatic and upsetting time for me but the way that my friends and other community members have been treated upsets me greatly. 
A game as beautiful and accepting as this should have a community that reflects that, instead it's caused harm to a group of people who were only trying to help and engage. 
Download the game, have the most amazing time because I promise you 100% you will. Catch fish, grow wheat, ride a bike into the river (trust me it's far too easy to ride a bike into a river). My god the world has been waiting for a game like this for way too long... but maybe give that invite to the discord a miss.

139631449.review:
The game itself is cool, I loved it and I wrote quite a few mods for it and even became a moderator on the Discord.

Sadly the Community Manager shoos good people away from the community out of spite and defends bigots and harassers while at it. Three women (including me) got harassed out of the server by another moderator (guess what, a man!), and all the CM did was crazy mental gymnastics to protect him and put the blame on us. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

Disappointed, but not surprised.

The developer knows it all and made it clear he stands for all of it, so the game is now dead to me and I cannot recommend it. All that coziness was just a mere facade.

139577881.review:
[h1] Dinkum [/h1] 

Dinkum is an [b]extraordinary game[/b] that effortlessly transports players into a realm of tranquility, offering a welcome escape from the realities of everyday life. From the moment you embark on your journey, you'll be enchanted by its serene landscapes, delightful gameplay mechanics, and the sheer joy it brings.

One of the most exceptional qualities of Dinkum is its ability to create an atmosphere of complete relaxation. Whether you're seeking solace after a long day or simply craving a break from the chaos of the world, this game provides a haven of calmness. Its soothing visuals, enchanting soundscapes, and gentle pace combine harmoniously to create a truly serene experience. It's like stepping into a virtual sanctuary where worries fade away, leaving only a blissful sense of peace.

Dinkum's gameplay is not only relaxing but also incredibly fun. As you delve deeper into its enchanting world, you'll discover a myriad of activities and challenges that keep you engaged and entertained for hours on end. The game seamlessly blends exploration, resource gathering, and creative problem-solving, ensuring that every moment feels fresh and exciting. Whether you're tending to your virtual garden, fishing in tranquil lakes, or engaging in captivating quests, Dinkum's gameplay is an absolute delight.

One of the most intriguing aspects of Dinkum is its emphasis on finding new and better ways to earn money. Rather than simply rewarding mindless grinding, the game encourages you to think strategically and innovatively. It presents a range of options, from establishing a bustling marketplace to nurturing a thriving farm, allowing you to craft your own path to prosperity. This dynamic system fosters a sense of accomplishment and satisfaction as you witness your efforts bear fruit and your virtual wealth grow.

Furthermore, Dinkum's flexibility is a true testament to its brilliance. It can be enjoyed anytime, anywhere, making it the perfect companion for those seeking a temporary reprieve from reality. Whether you have a few spare minutes during a commute or desire a lengthier session in the comfort of your own home, Dinkum is always there to whisk you away to a world of serenity and joy.

In summary, Dinkum is an extraordinary game that offers a mesmerizing and relaxing escape from the demands of everyday life. With its tranquil ambiance, engaging gameplay, and the opportunity to explore new and inventive ways to earn money, it provides an unparalleled experience that leaves players feeling refreshed and invigorated. Dinkum is a true gem, a testament to the power of gaming as a medium for joy, relaxation, and personal growth.

139543256.review:
An amazing relaxing - but if you want - also action filled holiday, where you can build a farm as well as a city. If you have the patience to do it, you can reshape and reform the whole map, which reminds me very much of Minecarft or Dragon Quest Builders. The freedom to do so, while this place you create is also inhabited by other people to make the world feel less empty, is a great adition.

So what can make it better? A few ideas came into my mind, but I don't intend them as complaint, just as an inspiration:
Maybe tourists a few more residents would come - how about some workers to hire for farming, mining and fishing, musicians, writer/poets, artists as friend of the guy running the museum, a pilot/ferryman for the residents? Or the possibility to run a streetfood-stall, where you can sell your stuff to the residents? It also would be nice, if someone with interior decoration ambitions could change the interior and the exterior of the residents houses. And how about family members of the residents, like old parents or brothers and sisters? Granny can't be the only old person on the island... And how about a starwatch tower, a music hall, a cinema and a hotel?

139029008.review:
Fans of Animal Crossing, Stardew Valley and Minecraft would absolutely love this game! 

There's so much to do and explore! Comparing it to the other games listed above, all the items have a purpose, there's more to craft, you can explore your island in different ways, there's lots of animals to take care of or hunt, and so much more. There's no way you can rush through this game. 

If you like decorating and is concerned about filling your island up too fast, don't worry! Your island is MASSIVE! There's so much land to explore that you couldn't finish decorating or laying everything out within a short period of time. There's also lots of recipes and items to discover as well as visitors to bring to your island.

One of my favourite things is DInkum's online co-op. You can have up to 4 players per island, AND there's no restriction to what you and your friends can do on each other islands. It's a great help especially when you go down to the mines, need to fight an alpha or even to get materials around the island. 

Overall, for the price of this game it is well worth your money. There's endless stuff to do and lots of tips and tricks to learn along the way!

Animal Crossing with an Aussie twist.  Light hearted, slightly addictive fun.  Watch out for them Wary Mu's and the Croco's hiding in the waterholes and you should be golden.
Still in Early Access but already so much to do, collect and build. 
Cons; movement can take some practice as it's square by square in the direction you're facing, so it can get a bit frustrating sometimes when you are aiming at things, and can make combat annoying when trying to dodge attacks. 
Days are also very short.  By the time you do some basic maintenance around your town the day's half gone, and some of the vendors have very short opening hours, so if you need to shop don't go far before you can visit them.  
Other than a few bugs with wording and quest dialog telling me the wrong things when I'm handing them in, I can't really fault it as a cute little timewasting builder/crafter.  
Warning; may chew up more of your time than you anticipate.

138349681.review:
Let me preface this by saying this game is VERY good. It's hard to stop playing sometimes. There's a lot to like about this game, and there are also some areas that could use improvement. Below are some points I hope are implemented.

1: Manual Save Functionality - Probably the only real annoyance I have is that the only way to save the game (aside from using the debug console cheats) is by sleeping to end the day. Often I will do the "morning routine" of watering crops, tending to animals, getting the NPC daily tasks, etc., which will usually take until mid-afternoon. There's still a lot of time left in the day to go into the deep mines, go out and collect materials, etc., but I sometimes will be pulled away or just want to stop, and I have to choose between just ending the day there or redoing it all. I strongly believe there should be a way to save the game without ending the day.

2: Bugs and Fish in Containers - I feel that bugs and fish should be able to be stored in containers. It was annoying to have to go get a specific one when an NPC requested it, when I had previously caught it and had to sell/drop it to make room (this was before learning you can place them on the ground. However, this still gets cluttered when you have a lot of them, and it can get hard to tell which is which). Perhaps special containers can be locked behind licenses or bought from Franklyn or Julia.

3: Crafting and Automation - Some of the first mods I look for in games with crafting systems are mods for inventory management and crafting automation. By the end of the first in-game year, I had a lot of chests, and just one day in the deep mines could net up to 200 ore. I think it could be satisfying to have some options for improved crafting and processing. Perhaps some Franklyn commissions for a special crafting table that pulls from boxes that are in specific squares, special boxes that feed into adjacent production items, etc.

4: Wheelbarrow - I think the wheelbarrow has extremely limited uses currently. It is nice if you want to transport dirt a small distance, but that usually isn't something I've needed, and by the time I did, I had the dirt printer. I think if the wheelbarrow could place its contents in the square in front of it one at a time, it could serve as a nice in-between before you have the dirt printer, and it would have a lot more utility.

5: Silos - Placing animal feed into silos should require a single click to place the entire stack you're holding. There is no reason to place them one at a time, and it is tedious to have to click 200 times to completely fill one. Even just topping one off after a few days of use kind of defeats the purpose of it automatically filling the feeders if you have to click the same number of times anyway.

6: Crab Pots - Currently, crab pots feel pretty disappointing. Being locked behind the 3000 perk point fishing license and requiring a total of 35 ore *per pot* is a lot. Then, each requires some meat to bait every day (which really adds up when you make a lot of them), and each only catches a single item per day, which is usually a common item you could get a bunch of anyway. It either shouldn't be able to catch anything other than some of the more rare critters, should catch multiple things per day, or it should cost much less to craft. For similar materials, you could just make an animal pen and get consistently more valuable items to sell from processing animal products and spend 1 animal feed per day instead of 1 meat.

All this being said, most of these points are addressed by mods (bless this game's modding community), and again the game is still very fun and engaging (I also love the soundtrack!). I hope James sees this and takes these points into consideration.

138216080.review:
Donating to the museum does not work as described.
Everywhere I look it says it's individual player progress, which is not the case, the individual player receives tickets but the donations count towards the hosts progression and prevents the host from being able to donate the same creature. I don't understand why the explanation on the wiki isn't as simple as the way I have worded it.

If players do not load into the next day before the host quits, all player progress is lost.
The shop is often bugged on mondays in multiplayer.
The shop is often bugged on wednesdays in multiplayer.
3 days where you can't sell or buy some weeks.

Ted Selly's visiting concept is absurd, you must explore the entire map and get a notification about a whistle.
He may not be there.
You may spend an entire day searching your island.

There is bread.
There is bananas.
There is no banana bread.

Combat breaks quite frequently in multiplayer sessions.
Fishing is best done when you're not the host as latency allows fishing to become redundant, bring the lure close to you and 1 click on bite and fish is caught - this is for some reason, not a viable tactic as a host, the fish bites, you act as if you catch something, but receive nothing using this tactic *as a host*

This is a very fun game for Animal Crossing fans, it just needs a lot of TLC and polish, though I fear that some of these bugs, as they are well known and have existed for some time, are embedded in the core code of the game and won't be fixed soon, if ever. 

I hope that these notes become redundant and the game receives the TLC it needs.
It is a solid 7/10 but difficult to recommend when hiccups in gameplay make you feel like you wasted a lot of time and effort and are permanently locked out of receiving currency for progression.

As of this review, I've played for about 40 hours and so far am enjoying this game. 
It feels like a cross between Stardew and Animal Crossing, but it takes what is best from them and makes a better game. Don't get me wrong, I love Stardew, but I always feel like I don't have enough time to do anything. Maybe 190 hours isn't a lot for some people, but I felt like I played it a lot. And well Animal Crossing is rather boring, just by watching it. With Dinkum, you have slower progression, but it feels just quick enough for you to learn the game. Sure, not everything is explained, but sometimes the people you talk to will give you advice that helps. I could see how some people might not enjoy the slower progression if they like to min/max etc., but I like it. I haven't felt rushed, even when I feel like I'm not doing all that much. I know I could be doing more with my days, but there is no rush. Just sit back and chill, unless you're in the mine ofc. 
Oh and before I forget, so far it has the best fishing experience I've had in a game that isn't just a fishing game. It's closer to a realistic experience and I love it.  Actually my favourite thing to do.
I highly recommend this game if you love chill games. It's very well done, especially for one person to have done all of this.  One of the best games ever gifted to me.

I recently played Dinkum for a total of 16 hours, and I have to say, it was a great experience. The multiplayer feature was top-notch, and I encountered no bugs throughout my gameplay. The graphics and sound were impressive and added to the overall enjoyment of the game.

Dinkum is a fun game that kept me engaged for hours on end. The controls were easy to learn, and the gameplay was smooth and seamless. The multiplayer mode was particularly enjoyable, as I was able to team up with other players and take on challenges together. It added a whole new level of excitement and strategy to the game.

One of the things I appreciated most about Dinkum was the attention to detail. The graphics were well-designed, and the sound effects were spot on. The game truly transports you to a different world, immersing you in the gameplay and making you feel like you're part of the action.

Overall, I highly recommend Dinkum to anyone looking for a fun and engaging game to play. It's well-designed, has great graphics and sound, and the multiplayer mode is top-notch. After playing for 16 hours, I can confidently say that Dinkum is one of the best games I've played in a long time.

137590688.review:
I wanted to leave a note for one singular reason: this is the first game where the volume wasn't maxed at the start, and didn't end up blowing out my eardrums as a result. The master volume slider starts at around 30%, which is fantastic - can every game be like this please?

Regarding the 'recommendation' for this game - I am refunding it; it's not one I see myself playing in the long term (plus the sounds were really bothering me). That said..

tl;dr : It tries its hardest to be Animal Crossing, but just isn't - though it certainly feels like it's well on that path. Maybe with some quality-of-life updates it can get a lot closer, but - wasn't for me. To be fair, I was never the biggest Animal Crossing player to begin with - so if you were, it may be more palatable.

Good:
(1) Serious Animal Crossing [Switch]/Nintendo vibes - if you enjoyed that game, this one is very likely up your alley - at least with regards to the graphics/ui/overall feel of the game off the bat.

Bad:
(1) The sound effects - the developers sure love their extremely high-pitched/grating sounds, for everything. List: [UI menu clicks for everything/Pickaxe mining sound/even the occasional footstep sound] - they're all just... incredibly irritating, like nails on a chalkboard.
(2) The inventory system - like Animal Crossing, it offers a toolbar+backpack organization of your items. That itself isn't bad, but - unlike Animal Crossing, there is no rotating through your backpack/toolbars - there's only a singular bar you can put things on. I found myself CONSTANTLY having to open up the backpack and move things around, which as a controller player was just time-consuming/obnoxious. Seriously, just do it the way Animal Crossing [Switch] does, and it'd feel SO much better.
(3) Selling items - there's no way to see how much each item sells for, as a single unit, or as a stack; when you hover over your items at a merchant, or try to find them in the informational menus. You select everything you want to sell, and John just gives you a price - that's it. I'm sure I could sell him one item at a time and note how much each thing sells for - but come on, that's unrealistic.

Excelente y muy divertido, la fórmula de juego recuerda muchisimo a Stardew Valley mezclado con Animal Crossing, una mezcla que no sabía que necesitaba tanto además de ser un deleite para los fans del farmeo y upgradear tus herramientas, edificios y estaciones de trabajo, dicho esto tengo un par de problemas que si bien no afectan en nada a la jugabilidad pienso que son detalles que podrían ser atendidos facilmente:

1.- Problemas de Z-figthing: hay algunas ocasiones en que las texturas o modelos se llegan a sobreponer de manera que crean este efecto de parpadeo que queda algo raro.
por ejemplo al pasar varios troncos por la sierra y dejar que se acumulen las tablas de madera en el suelo, llegando a ser más notorio cuando cortamos diferentes tipos de madera.
O también al cargar objetos como panales o las conchas grandes sobre la cabeza, si tenemos un sombrero colocado se nota mucho el efecto entre los modelos, siendo el más notorio con el sombrero de copa.

2.- Opciones graficas: Aunque ciertamente el juego no es muy exigente a nivel de requerimientos gráficos, pienso que estaría muy bien que se añadiesen más opciones para controlar el apartado de la calidad de los gráficos, es decir, poder manipular más opciones como las sombras, la calidad de los modelos, los reflejos, efectos de particulas, etc. Esto claro de cara a poder hacer la experiencia más accesible para las personas con computadores menos potentes.

137500610.review:
*WIP review while I play through the game*

Pros: The game is moddable, which trust me, it needs it! There's several issues with the game that modders fortunately solved. God bless the modding community, I tell ya.

The game has good regional pricing (for the most part)

Cons: The game only has a singular save file AND the game ONLY saves when you go to sleep at the end of the day. Now, considering that you can spend upwards of 30minutes on a single day, this means that if the game were to crash at any time during the day, then you lose ALL that progress made during the day and lose all loot. And since the game crashes every so often, that means you're going to lose hours of gameplay if you invest any meaningful amount of time into playing the game. The dev could easily fix this by implementing a save system that ISN'T straight out of the year 1995.

A single butterfly/spider/etc. takes up a whole inventory slot, but you can have 20 engines on 1 inventory slot. Makes sense?

Because of the above inventory stacking design decision, the inventory is far too small, and it rightfully should be increased by at least 10 spaces.

Weapons/Tools/etc. break when they reach zero durability, meaning you lose them forever.

Your stamina/energy bar comes 1/10th of the size when you go past 00:00 at night, and you LOSE all stamina that you had above that line. A [u]MUCH[/u] better mechanic would be to instead simply not allow the player to recoup their stamina after the 00:00 time.

Bats in the mines don't give any loot, ever. They're the only thing in the game that doesn't give loot AND they're the only thing in the game that can't be hit by weapons in a straight forward fashion. Two things that make no sense in the logic of the game.

There's some special animals in the game, like Radioactive Crocs for instance, but these animals give no special loot besides the regular Croc loot. This is pretty stupid imo as there's zero incentive to hunt these special animals.

137408758.review:
I’ve waited weeks to write this review, to ensure I knew the game well. 220 hours of gameplay later, here we go. 

Dinkum is a charming, creative, well executed title. It is essentially Animal Crossing style gameplay, in a little Australian world. A delight to play and addictive to those who don’t mind a little grind.

Speaking of grind, the grind in early game won’t last forever, Dinkum manages to balance the work / reward mechanic to near perfection. Work hard, reap the benefits and when everything seems to be in abundance, there’s still a lot to do. 

Negatives? Honestly, I love it so much it’s difficult to come up with any. It is in early access, so there’s a few bugs, but they’re far from terrible (and the dev is very in touch with community feedback). 

Buy Dinkum, it’s a wonderful experience that just goes on and on. Made by one guy… it’s a miracle and he’s still iterating.

One of the best missing games I played this year without exaggeration. Here's why (after 52 hours of play)
It will be a long speech, in which I will explain some details and say the missing things

The movement of the camera is unique in this game and smooth, and the smoothness of the game even in entering and exiting buildings at high speed without a loading screen is a beautiful thing that I cannot describe accurately

The graphics of the game are beautiful and cartoony, not exaggerated, such as trying to reach realism, because games always fail in that, except rarely

Everyone in the city has special interests and also different working times, and you can chat with them and give you advice or tell their life stories (the dialogues will be special at the beginning of the game and become repeated later), and you can befriend any individual and go out with them, but before that you must carry out several tasks for them in order for the love meter to increase And they become your friends, but their programming is not good. Unfortunately, I sometimes have problems with them, such as delay in reactions.

In short, the game will be excellent, like the first 30, 40, 50, or 60 hours, after which you will notice a lack of activities and repetition of tasks, but it is not a big problem, especially since the game is early access.

Here are the missing things that I wish were present in the game

The map becomes larger and more diverse, and there are different cities in it that you cannot modify. You only deal with them, such as trading or buying from their stores, and their products are different from those of your city, so that you are encouraged to go to them.

More diversity in environments, changing the desert from red to beige, adding a snowy and mountainous area and a green area

When winter came, I wished that the land, trees, and buildings would be covered with snow, and the lighting of the game would change to be more white, and in the fall, the leaves would fall and fill the land, and the sunlight would be orange

Add more wild animals such as bears, lions, hyenas, etc

Adding legendary animals whose sizes are larger and more difficult to hunt, and that there is a shop that buys the skins or heads of these animals from you at high prices to encourage hunting them and their places differ such as land, seas and sky, on land, for example, there will be a bear, and in the sea, for example, it will be Megaldon, and in the sky will be the eagle

Adding a larger and wider aquatic life, and the possibility of buying a diving suit or a submarine to explore it, or to catch more or larger fish

Adding more modifications to the houses, more colors, and adding a garage

Add NPCs Interact in town

Adding more mini games, for example, an arcade game store, or any fun side activity

Adding dinosaur fossils to the museum, and the bones are collected and restored by the player

I apologize for the prolongation. The bottom line is that the game has great potential, and the more developers are interested in their game, the more and more the success of the game will be. Therefore, I hope to add continuous updates, whether new or to fix glitch.
